clinical_study.brief_title: Functional Outcome Anterior Cruciate Ligament Reconstruction
clinical_study.official_title: Comparison of Functional Outcome Measures of Anterior Cruciate Ligament Reconstruction Using Either Patellar Tendon or Hamstring Tendon Grafts and Controls in Competitive Soccer Players: A Randomized Trial

lead_sponsor.agency: University of Social Welfare and Rehabilitation Science

clinical_study.source: University of Social Welfare and Rehabilitation Science

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to compare hop performance and jump landing strategy in soccer players with higher level sports activities after ACLR using either BPTB or STG and controls.

detailed_description.textblock: The choice of graft for anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction (ACLR) remains controversial. Despite the need for outcome studies comparing bone-patellar tendon-bone (BPTB) with semitendinosus and gracilis tendon (STG), few studies have evaluated functional outcomes. The objective of the current study was to compare hop performance and jump landing strategy in soccer players with higher level sports activities after ACLR using either BPTB or STG and controls.

primary_outcome.measure: Hop values for the both legs in Single, 6-m, Cross-over and Triple hops
primary_outcome.time_frame: Patients were followed up to 8 months post-surgery

secondary_outcome.measure: Landing and Take-off Ground Reaction Forces
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Patients were followed up to 8 months post-surgery
Patients were followed up to 8 months post-surgery

clinical_study.condition: Complications of Surgical Procedures or Medical Care

study_pop.textblock: The patients with ACL deficiency were invited to participate in a randomized trial comparing ACLR with either a BPTB or STG graft.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- ACLR and controls.
Exclusion Criteria:
